topics.body:
You know if mind reading was real you know what I would do with it?  Constantly finish everyone's sentences and never tell anyone about it.

"So I was telling them that there's no way that-"
"-the professor would fall for that excuse"
"Stop interrupting me!  As I was saying; so then I tell him that a better way would be to -"
"-tell the professor that your car broke down?"

topics.body:
You know I'm starting to realize why C++ is so difficult to understand and why programming is so hard to understand.  It's not that it's hard to learn, yes it is hard to learn, but the mindset of "RTFM".

The problem with this is that I don't have the book yet so how can someone learn from the book if they don't have the book.

I found a online lesson that answered my question within the first two minutes.  So yeah I'm going to be paying attention to this guy cause he actually explains it instead of going, "lol read it yourself".  Honestly this kind of pisses me off cause the purpose of a professor is to teach obviously, but if they don't teach then are they actually a professor?  What I mean by this is what seems to be a huge problem with teaching programming is that professors don't do what is required in their job and expect the student to already learn.  The logical fallacy with this is that would be like a swimming instructor throwing a kid who can't swim into a swimming pool or a parachute instructor throwing a person out of a plane; the fallacy of this is that if you throw a kid who can't swim into a swimming pool there's a high chance they're going to drown or if you throw person out of plane they're going to go splat.

If you're a teacher or professor keep in mind this logical fallacy in that if you were a driving instructor would you first day have the student drive in New York traffic?  If you say yes then you massively need to rethink your teaching strategy.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
